ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I begin to think critically, and can have a better logic in my writing, and are brave enough to share my opinion.

1. Reading
2. Writing 
3. Thinking

Philosophical thinking on political and international relationships related questions.
Essay writing skills.
The ways to develop a clear and specific outline for papers.
i gain deeper understanding about US politics especially about Trump and how he stirred the fact around US political situation
A take on more philosophical approach in politics and a new, necessary insight in receiving opinions and information.

The course enhanced my reading and writing abilities. The readings offered profound insights into contemporary US politics and society, all while being reasonably manageable in volume. With the help of Professor Vogel and Elyse, I also improved a lot in writing philosophy papers and argumentative essays in general.

Trust and Mistrust provide a deep philosophical thinking for phenomenon in the real world. From this course, I develop a curiosity and realization that even trust can be masked by many interest surround it. I also learn a lot about the complexity of politics that utilize numerous aspect in life to 'manipulate' the society.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strength: fully discussion and detailed feedback.

Strengths
1. Discussions and engagement in class are encouraged
2. Many readings and weekly writings (Opportunities to read, write, and think throughout the course)
3. Up-to-date topics
4. Relatively smaller sized class
5. Well-structured syllabus.
6. Engaging topics for assignments.

There were no weaknesses.
the students are so smart and engaging. their opinion are always eye-opening.

I really enjoy how the course includes political aspects in many part of the materials. But unfortunately, the more the class continues, it became less philosophical and more leaning into political beliefs; sometimes I feel cornered to answer questions as right and wrong, even though in philosophy you are allowed to have personal approach. I have a hard time understanding the class and I also felt like the class turn into a competition every discussions.

The equilibrium between students voicing out our interpretations and Professor Vogel's teaching struck a perfect chord. Both facets of the course were very informative and thought-provoking. Our teaching assistant, Elyse Boldt, was also extremely helpful and knowledgeable. I think her assistance was also a great part of the course's value. 

While the course itself was exceptional, I would say that sometimes the discussion on one or a few of the readings becomes so heated that we no longer have time to discuss the other ones. Probably lengthening each class would be helpful.

Strengths: insightful class discussion, thorough feedback in assignments, and very helpful teaching staffs
Weakness: the clarity of expected outcomes in assignment, I think? it was hard for me to wrap my head around the explanation about assignments and its expected outcome

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, because the course can bring excellent views for me.
Yes. This class is unique compared to other classes because students can learn to connect philosophical thinking with the recent news in the practical realm.
yes. because the topic is very interesting despite it might be a challenge to understand US politics if you are not from there. but the reading material helps a lot to tackle the challenge.

This course would undoubtedly appeal not only to students of philosophy and political science but also to anyone seeking deeper insights into the contemporary world, liberal democracy, and the trust crisis. The readings draw from not only past philosophers but also contemporary media outlets, and the discussions frequently refer to the societal and political situations of a variety of nations.

Definitely! Trust and Mistrust debunk my own doubts in taking philosophical class. I always perceive philosophy as an abstract thing--well, it is, but Prof. Vogel and Elyse did a great job to make the class way more digestable--even for someone who never took a philosophy class before.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: view things through another perspective that I learn in this course.

I will apply the reading skills that I learned from this course to learn things faster and more effectively. The way I read any kind of text, from newspapers to academic papers, changed after taking this course. Instead of losing my focus on minor details, I now focus on the main point of each paragraph or the whole article. It is helping me grasp any information better.

The course provided me an insight to the subject philosophy.
The writing skills practiced will no doubt boos my study in college.
The booklist that Elyse and professor Vogel recommended will definitely help me to know more about philosophy and international relationship.
i will try to apply everything i learnt from this class to Indonesia political circumstances as it is also near the general election in 2024. I hope I could use the knowledge in a good terms
The information on the U.S. politics is very useful for my major, and I plan to learn more about it.

This course ignited a passion for political philosophy within me, and I'm even contemplating a future major/minor in this field. The insights into the contemporary world far exceeded my expectations of a philosophy course. I'm eager to apply what I've learned in discussions with my peers and in my own writing.
I will use it as a way of thinking, especially because I will do my final thesis soon. It will help me to dig deep into phenomenon in real world by asking philosophical question.

extras.title: HUMS S332 01/PHIL S350 01/PLSC S281 01 - Trust–and Mistrust
